content:
Sure, here are some specific albums from these African artists to start with:

1. Amadou & Mariam - "Welcome to Mali": This album features a mix of traditional Malian music and modern rock, and includes collaborations with Manu Chao, Damon Albarn, and Keziah Jones. 

2. Angelique Kidjo - "Remain in Light": This album is a cover of the Talking Heads' classic album of the same name, infused with Kidjo's own unique African style. 

3. Seun Kuti & Egypt 80 - "From Africa with Fury: Rise": Seun Kuti and Egypt 80 continue the Afrobeat legacy of Seun's father, Fela Kuti, with this album, which blends traditional African rhythms with modern instrumentation. 

4. Tinariwen - "Elwan": This album features Tinariwen's signature blend of traditional Tuareg music and rock, and was recorded in the Sahara Desert. 

5. Burna Boy - "African Giant": This album features Burna Boy's unique blend of Afrobeat, dancehall, and reggae, and includes collaborations with Jorja Smith, Damian Marley, and Angelique Kidjo. 

6. Sauti Sol - "Midnight Train": This album features Sauti Sol's unique fusion of East African rhythms, R&B, and pop, and includes collaborations with India Arie and Soweto Gospel Choir. 

7. Oumou Sangaré - "Mogoya": This album features Oumou Sangaré's take on traditional Wassoulou music, infused with contemporary influences, including jazz and electronic music. 

8. Sho Madjozi - "Limpopo Champions League": This album features Sho Madjozi's unique blend of traditional Tsonga music and modern hip hop, and includes collaborations with Nigerian artists Ycee and Nneka. 

9. Nasty C - "Zulu Man With Some Power": This album features Nasty C's fusion of traditional African music with modern hip hop, and includes collaborations with Ari Lennox, T.I., and Lil Gotit. 

10. Omah Lay - "Get Layd": This EP features Omah Lay's blend of Afro-fusion and R&B, and includes the hit singles "Bad Influence" and "Ye Ye Ye".
